A U.S.
Marine accused of a massacre had a chance to tell his side of the story.
Staff Sergeant Frank Wuterich led a squad that killed 24 civilians in the Iraqi town of Haditha.
He faces multiple counts of unpremeditated murder.
NPR's John McChesney reports on Wuterich's hearing yesterday at Camp Pendleton, California.
Sergeant Wuterich delivered his un-sworn statement in crisp military style - without emotion.
He said he would never be okay with what happened November 19th, 2005.
He lost a Marine to a roadside bomb just outside Haditha in the pre-dawn hours.
He said he got out of his Humvee, remained calm, and immediately shot five Iraqi males who were running away from a white taxi.
That they were running away is a major point of dispute in this case.
Under immunity from murder charges, another squad member testified that some of the men had their hands on their heads and weren't running.
Defense lawyers say he's lying.
During the hearing there were long debates about the rules of engagement, the legal rules governing the use of force in Iraq.
One Marine legal officer testified that it's not legal to shoot just anyone running away from a roadside bomb site.
Sgt.
Wuterich says he thought the men beside the taxi might be trigger men.
Following the shooting of the men near the taxi, Wuterich's squad assaulted two houses nearby, killing 19 more civilians.
He said today that hostile fire was coming from one of those houses, but the source of hostile fire, if there was any at all, is in dispute.
In any case, Wuterich told investigators that he told his men to shoot first and ask questions later.
Earlier, a military instructor testified that if you say shoot first, then everyone is expendable.
And that's not acceptable.
The investigative officer overseeing the hearing will make a recommendation as to whether Wuterich should face a court martial.
John McChesney, NPR News.

Now here's that other complication with medical research.
Giant drug companies have come up with so many successful drugs, they are having trouble finding better ones.
Consider this case from over the weekend.
Pfizer said it is stopping development of a new drug that would treat heart disease by raising so-called good cholesterol.
Early results from a large study show the drug actually increased heart problems and deaths.
The setback shows how hard it is to keep up the industry's phenomenal growth.
Here's NPR's Snigdha Prakash.
This is hardly the first time that a promising blockbuster drug has blown up before it gets to market.
But the scale and the impact of this disaster could hardly be more dramatic.
The drug, torcetrapib, was Pfizer's answer to a problem that most drug companies are facing: a rash of patent expirations that'll wipe out profits for many of their bestsellers.
Torcetrapib was to replace earnings from the cholesterol-lowering statin drug Lipitor, which accounts for a whopping 50 percent of Pfizer's earnings and goes off patent in 2011.
Torcetrapib's demise, says analyst Jaime Rubin of Morgan Stanley, is simply devastating.
Basically, we think Pfizer now is unlikely to show any organic or top line growth, meaningful growth, for another 10 years.
There are many explanations for why growth at Pfizer and other drug companies could slow way down.
First, the new drugs have to fill big shoes.
Several companies are investing in finding drugs that raise good cholesterol or HDL levels, because they're considered the single most promising market of the future.
But will there ever another Lipitor?
Who knew that Lipitor was going to be a $13 billion drug?
Nobody.
Analyst Jaime Rubin says it's not easy to develop a drug with comparable annual sales.
Cardiologist Eric Topol of Case Western University offers another reason why the industry can't rely on new HDL drugs to maintain the high growth rates of the past.

Topol says existing cardiac drugs already work so well that it's difficult to find a new drug that adds meaningful benefits in patients who already take four or five drugs everyday: aspirin, a statin to lower cholesterol, drugs to lower blood pressure, a blood thinner to prevent clots, and so on.

I really think that the opportunity to develop a drug to be used in tens of millions of people, like statins - the chance for that in patients with heart disease is incredibly remote in the years ahead.

Analyst Richard Evans of Sanford Bernstein and Company says torcetrapib's safety problems might raise costs and delay new HDL drugs because the Food and Drug Administration will be scrutinizing this class of drugs more closely.
I think the agency is going to require longer trials, and these are going to be more expensive than what the industry otherwise would have had to do.
The drugs being tested in those trials may also just be plain more risky, which will also make it harder to come up with new bestsellers, says analyst Tim Anderson of Prudential Securities.
You're looking at a drug industry that for the last six years has been pretty desperate to get new products to market.
And companies, because of their desperation, they're more willing to move riskier compounds into later stages of development because, essentially, that's all they have.

All this is happening at a time when companies are under increasing pressure for insurers to hold their prices in check, drug usages isn't climbing like it used to, and the federal government could try to hold Medicare prices down.
The pharmaceutical industry is still very profitable by any standards, but analysts say that Pfizer's recent problems show why maintaining and expending those profits is getting harder.
Snigdha Prakash, NPR News, Washington.
